content.question: A continuous function f is defined on the closed interval <math> <mrow> <mo> − </mo> <mn> 4 </mn> <mo> ≤ </mo> <mi> x </mi> <mo> ≤ </mo> <mn> 6 </mn> </mrow> </math> . The graph of f consists of a line segment and a curve that is tangent to the x -axis at x = 3, as shown in the figure above. On the interval 0 < x < 6, the function f is twice differentiable, with f'' ( x ) > 0. (a) Is f differentiable at x = 0? Use the definition of the derivative with one-sided limits to justify your answer.

frqParts.text: A continuous function f is defined on the closed interval <math> <mrow> <mo> − </mo> <mn> 4 </mn> <mo> ≤ </mo> <mi> x </mi> <mo> ≤ </mo> <mn> 6 </mn> </mrow> </math> . The graph of f consists of a line segment and a curve that is tangent to the x -axis at x = 3, as shown in the figure above. On the interval 0 < x < 6, the function f is twice differentiable, with f'' ( x ) > 0. (a) Is f differentiable at x = 0? Use the definition of the derivative with one-sided limits to justify your answer.

(b) For how many values of a , <math> <mrow> <mo> − </mo> <mn> 4 </mn> <mo> ≤ </mo> <mi> a </mi> <mo> < </mo> <mn> 6 </mn> </mrow> </math> , is the average rate of change of f on the interval [ a , 6] equal to 0? Give a reason for your answer.

(c) Is there a value of a, −4 ≤ a < 6, for which the Mean Value Theorem, applied to the interval [a, 6], guarantees a value c, a < c < 6, at which <math> <semantics> <mrow> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>c</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mn>1</mn> <mn>3</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C67@</annotation> </semantics> </math>? Justify your answer.

(d) The function g is defined by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mi>x</mi> </msubsup> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi><mtext> for </mtext><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>6</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4F48@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. On what intervals contained in [-4, 6] is the graph of g concave up? Explain your reasoning.

topic.text: 2.1: Defining Average and Instantaneous Rates of Change at a Point

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Identify mathematical information from graphical, numerical, analytical, and/or verbal representations.
